reviewText: This is the tale of two Czechoslovakian film directors, Ivan Passer and Milos Forman.  They were colleagues in the Czech "New Wave" during the mid-1960's, when creative freedom was loosened in the Soviet bloc country, and internationally recognized films were produced (Forman's LOVES OF A BLONDE and THE FIREMAN'S BALL; Passer's INTIMATE LIGHTING).  This culminated in the Prague Spring, a few short months of political and artistic flowering in 1968, when reformists came to power, and it felt like all things were possible in the Eastern European nation.  But then in August, the Soviet military and other members of the Warsaw pact invaded Czechoslovakia, bringing a violent, abrupt end to the reforms.  Artists were driven from the country, including Forman and Passer, who both defected to the United States.So, two filmmakers, on pretty much equal footing, escape repression and come to America in the late 1960's.  One of them - Forman - reaches the pinnacle of Hollywood glory twice, winning Academy Awards for Best Director and Best Picture for ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST and AMADEUS.  The other - Passer - seems to barely scrape by.  It's not as if Passer hasn't turned out quality work.  His 1974 comedy, LAW AND DISORDER, was a quirky look at American crime and mores, and in 1981 he directed the impressive, well-regarded murder mystery, CUTTER'S WAY.  But unlike Forman, Passer never landed the project that would give him a real Hollywood toehold. If nothing else, the two divergent careers provide a lesson in the vagaries of the film business.Which brings us to Ivan Passer's 1988 film, HAUNTED SUMMER.  Though it sounds like a horror movie, it's not.  Set in 1816, the film focuses on the famous summer when romantic poets Percy Shelley (Eric Stoltz) and Lord Byron (Philip Anglim) and their women, Claire Clairmont (Laura Dern) and Mary Wollstonecraft Godwin (Alice Krige) spent a debauched summer of free love, mind games and opium smoking in the Swiss Alps.  Amid the effete dialogue and literary posturing, the characters come off as superficial dopes.  The conceit of Lewis John Carlino's hopeless screenplay (from a novel by Anne Edwards) is that out of this vacation came the inspiration for Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley's (yes, she did marry the poet) novel, "Frankenstein," as well as Percy Shelley's poem, "Mont Blanc," which we see him gazing at in stoned wonder.Though the cast works hard to bring these characters to life, only Laura Dern is able to find an interesting take on the least-known of the four personalities.  Passer never seems to connect in any meaningful way with the material, and the budget he obviously had to work with limits his ability to give the film the scope that might have helped his cause.  Thus HAUNTED SUMMER becomes one more disappointing entry in Ivan Passer's filmography.  Given the triumphs and successes of his filmmaking compatriot, it's interesting to ponder the variables that can define a directing career.

reviewText: The DVD for this film begins with a disclaimer from MGM..."This film has been manufactured using the best source material available."What MGM neglected to include in that statement would most likely be the following admission...  "...the best source material available (lying around that was convenient for us to use and didn't involve any remastering or clean-up of the image.)"Which, from the look of the image, was probably the same source print that was used nearly twenty years ago when this film was put out on videotape since the image is full frame, not widescreen, and has that same fuzzy, blurry look to that most VHS tapes did back in the day. Not to mention lots of dirt and speckles on the image.  So good job, MGM! That is, if your idea of good work is making your customers dissatisfied and feeling ripped-off.

reviewText: I've seen almost every movie made (there are quite a few) about the summer of 1816, and the most famous literary house party in history. This one is the best. Lord Byron  is superbly portrayed by Philip Anglim, whose dark and brooding "Satanic majesty" also shows us the vulnerable, heartbroken man behind the cynic's mask. Eric Stolz' Shelley is a child of light, a perfect Sixties hippie, a "man of testicle" whose radical politics, open sexuality and easy acceptance of feminism put him centuries ahead of his time. Alice Krige renders a Mary who is the Mary Shelley of her biographers, Shelley's muse--serene, lovely, self-possessed. (My only quibble with the casting is that Krige, lovely and talented as she is, is still not convincing as a 19 year old, which is what Mary was when she sat down to write "Frankenstein".)Which brings me to the one serious--nearly fatal--flaw of this movie. There is not even a hint of the famous night of June 16, when Byron challenged everyone to write ghost stories and Mary was inspired to write "Frankenstein". From that night we got two of the most enduring creatures of horror in English literature: the Frankenstein monster, and the vampire. John Polidori, who here gets the ONLY honest treatment of him I've ever seen on film, was Byron's personal physician. When Byron abandoned his "ghost story" after ten paragraphs, Polidori took it up, completely rewrote it, and reinvented the vampire in Byron's image. "The Vampyre" was published several years after "Frankenstein", and became immensely popular. It influenced all subsequent ideas about vampires--the dark, brooding Byronic aristocrat who seduces women is based on Byron himself.That night of June 16, when the challenge was issued, should have been in this movie. It forms the whole basis of Mary Shelley's enduring fame; it gave us the vampire we know today. There is no reason to have left it out. It means there is no context to this movie, no way to assess the lasting importance of the ideas that these five were dealing with. The radical politics, the shared educational philosophy, the debate over whether evil exists and whether man is innately good, coupled with the personal issues of pregnancy and abandonment highlighted in this film, were all part of the mix that went into "Frankenstein". But unless those issues are tied to the art that expressed them, the film sort of flounders around without a point. Why should we care about these people? What made them so important? We get a couple of snippets of Byron and Shelley's poetry, but nothing whatsoever of "Frankenstein". The novel is never mentioned in the movie, and only referred to in one caption at the end (complete with the usual error of calling the Monster by his creator's name). No doubt the director and writer assumed their viewers would be as familiar with the background of "Frankenstein" as they were; unfortunately, I don't think that was the case.Matters are not helped by a subplot involving opium which is, IMO, just silly. Ignore it, and listen instead to the extemporare poetry, the trips to the lake, the table talk between two of the greatest poets in the English language.If you are at all familiar or interested in these immortals, this is a great and interesting film. See it. Read their books. Check out their legacies:Lord Byron: The Major Works (Oxford World's Classics)Shelley's Poetry and Prose (Norton Critical Edition)Frankenstein (Penguin Classics)The Vampyre (Forgotten Books)

reviewText: "Haunted Summer" is one of those films that fell through the cracks & sadly was overlooked by most viewers.  Being intrigued by the story's premise after seeing Ken Russell's similar film "Gothic" (which is also a wild ride to see in it's own right), I gave it a shot at the video store.  Although I enjoyed it then, it only got better with repeated viewings.  Each viewing invites thoughts of what the real life meeting between these characters of Lord Byron, Percy & Mary Shelley, Dr. Polidori & Claire Clairmont must have really been like.  I think I most enjoyed it's quiet peaceful moments, most notably the serene boat ride the main characters take while Laura Dern's character Claire sings her lovely song.  Also of note is the appropriately haunting & incredibly beautiful score by Christopher Young.  This amazing soundtrack is also sadly out of print at the moment.  Hopefully this hypnotic film will be released one day soon on DVD for all to experience & enjoy.  Anyone interested in this subject matter can also check out the film "Rowing With The Wind" (with Hugh Grant & Elizabeth Hurley) which is yet another take on this storyline.  All 3 films ("Haunted Summer", "Gothic" & "Rowing With The Wind") have points of interest for anyone exploring the subject matter, but sadly "Haunted Summer" which is the loveliest, is not yet available on DVD.VOTE FOR IT'S RELEASE ON DVD!
